page.title: 18ECOLOGY IN BOW AREA
page.content: Bow is a lowland area between Dartmoor and Exmoor, with high rainfall and cold winter winds. It comprises farmland with high hedgerows between undulating fields, small copses and marshes with streams. The fields have many insects, reptiles, birds and mammals: these include moths and butterflies; slowworms and grass snakes; swallows, skylarks, rooks and kestrels; moles and rabbits. Many hedges are several hundred years old. They are important wild life reservoirs giving cover for numerous plants and animals. The copses have pheasants, woodpeckers, owls and many smaller birds; they are also food for bats, squirrels, foxes and badgers. Flags and ragged robin are characteristic of marshes, & amphibia breed there, while fish, herons and occasional mink use the streams.
